ygData.subject: Re: MATLAB - segmentation violation error with equilibrate
ygData.msgSnippet: Thank you for the quick reply, Mr. Goodwin!! Well, I have to admit that big is a very relative statement. It s not big enough that I want to switch to C++

Thank you for the quick reply, Mr. Goodwin!!

Well, I have to admit that "b=
ig" is a very relative statement. It's 
not "big" enough that I want to swi=
tch to C++ because MATLAB offers 
some nice features I don't want to miss i=
n my project (GUI's, 
standard solver, etc..). And shame on me! :) I'm not =
quite familiar 
with python.

Nevertheless I also don't want to miss CANTER=
A!! 

I've tried some different "clear" options within MATLAB after the 
CA=
NTERA calls. It's just a sort of workaround but it seems like it 
will work=
 better now.
 
Destroying the MATLAB own variables can be done easily with =
"clear 
all". 

>>inmem
reveals the functions loaded. With "clear functions=
" one can free at 
least this memory. ("cleanup" doesn't do that). This wil=
l lower the 
performance of course.

Also think of any globals! They are no=
t destroyed with "clear all" in 
every workspace.


Thanks again!  

Tom

-=
-- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
>
> > Do=
es anybody know how to load and unload cantera related "stuff"
> > within s=
ubfunctions of big MATLAB codes in a definte way?
> 
> MATLAB has a number =
of limitations as a front end for Cantera, or 
any  
> C++ code.  The bigge=
st problem is that it does not provide a good 
way  
> to manage memory all=
ocation for cases where the MATLAB code calls 
C  
> or C++ code that alloc=
ates some memory.  MATLAB does not provide  
> "destructors" for classes, s=
o when an object created by a call to  
> "GRI30", for example, is deleted,=
 only the MATLAB variables are  
> released, not any memory allocated by Ca=
ntera.
> This is a fundamental limitation of the object model used in 
MATL=
AB,  
> unlike the much more robust object model of Python.
> 
> I always g=
et a bit nervous when I hear people describing "big"  
> calculations done =
using Cantera and MATLAB.  My recommendation 
would  
> be to switch to Pyt=
hon, or even go all the way to C++...
> >
> > p.s.: just a tip:
> > I've re=
cognized a "pointer like" behaviour of solution variables 
in
> > MATLAB.
>=
 > if you do something like:
> > g1=3DGRI30;
> > g2=3Dg1;
> > set(g1,'T',40=
0);
> > The set command will have effect on BOTH variables g1 and g2!!!!
> =
>
> The MATLAB objects just store pointers to the underlying C++ 
objects; =
 
> the statement "g2=3Dg1" copies the pointer. If you want a new,  
> inde=
pendent object, you have to call a constructor. So you would 
need  
> to w=
rite:
> g1=3DGRI30;
> g2=3DGRI30;
> instead of assigning g1 to g2.
> 
> >
>=
 >
> >
> >
> > Yahoo! Groups Links
> >
> >
> >
>
